articles.title: Skagit River Steelhead Season Not Likely To Open
articles.summary: The late winter and early spring catch-and-release season on the famed Skagit River may not happen in 2026, and not because of too few wild steelhead returning to the river. In fact, the numbers support a limited catch-and-release fishery with no retention of wild fish allowed.

articles.title: Flies That Catch Big Trout, The Truth Might Surprise You
articles.summary: I HAVE DEFINITE IDEAS ABOUT HOW TO CATCH BIG TROUT. APPARENTLY THEY ARE ALL WRONG. Like every other guy or gal with a fly rod, I have some pretty strong opinions about the kind of flies that catch big fish. These opinions are based on years of experience and experimentation.

articles.title: Tying Tuesday: Essential Winter Midges and Technical Nymphs
articles.summary: When winter temperatures settle in, trout slow down—and so must our approach. Success demands technical midge patterns and refined subsurface presentations that can fool even the most lethargic fish.

articles.title: Rubber, Above & Below
articles.summary: By Bob Reece Round rubber and spandex are two members in the vast tide of synthetic materials that have washed over the fly tying world in recent years. They have both been used to create numerous surface and subsurface patterns. However, I would argue that one is better suited for the world above while the other thrives below.

articles.title: The Drift: Do We Care Too Much About Fly Rods?
articles.summary: Last week, I wrote about my close encounter with a highly-collectible rod, the Winston 8’6″ 4-weight BIIt, nicknamed “The Staff of Moses.” I’m still kicking myself for not buying it (despite the $800+ price tag), but hopefully when the next one comes along, I’ll have some extra cash laying around.

articles.title: Skagit Steelhead Season Hangs by a Thread—Not for Lack of Fish, But Funding
articles.summary: As of mid-January, the highly anticipated catch-and-release season on Washington's Skagit and Sauk rivers—a bucket-list destination for steelhead anglers across the Pacific Northwest—stands on the verge of cancellation. The culprit isn't biology. It's bureaucracy.

articles.title: Sage Unveils Limited Edition Enforcer Grand Slam Reels: A Collector’s Dream for Flats Anglers
articles.summary: The three-model collection pays tribute to the legendary saltwater "Grand Slam"—the rare feat of landing a bonefish, permit, and tarpon in a single day.

articles.title: What Current Fly Rods Will Be Collectibles In 20 Years?
articles.summary: Some fly rods end up as more than just another entry in that year’s product catalog. A select few gain a cult following, often retaining their value (and exceeding their original retail price) as the years march on.

articles.title: What the 2026 Snow Drought Means for Your Summer Fly Fishing
articles.summary: While late-season storms could still turn the tide, the current deficits would require what water managers call a "miracle March" to offset. For now, keep an eye on the gauges—but start forming your plan B.
